GK19asvbc_2u:3: {title} A/svagho.sa's Buddhacarita: A machine readable transliteration
GK19asvbc_2u:21: {title} The Buddhacarita: Or, Acts of the Buddha. Part I -- Sanskrit Text {imprint}
GK19asvbc_2u:32: {title} The Buddha--Karita or Live of Buddha by Asvaghosha,
GK19asvbc_2u:33: Indian poet of the early second century after Christ. Sanskrit
GK19asvbc_2u:34: text, edited from a Devanagari and two Nepalese manuscripts with
GK19asvbc_2u:35: variant readings, a preface, notes and in index of names.
GK19asvbc_2u:38: {publisher} Oriental Press NV (orig. Oxford University Press)
GK19asvbc_2u:48: The text of the Johnston edition was transliterated on the basis of a cursory reading; the typed input was compared with the edition by Cowell, partly as a routine of proof--reading, partly in order to be able to add variant readings from the older
GK19asvbc_2u:49: edition. (The conventions for inputting variants are described
GK19asvbc_2u:50: below.) Proof--reading and insertion of variants was done
GK19asvbc_2u:51: "manually" and I do not guarantee completeness. The additional passages in Cowell at the beginning of the poem were not transliterated completely, and the additional chapters at the end were not transliterated at all.
GK19asvbc_2u:54: Punctuation marks are used to code diacritics. All diacritics are
GK19asvbc_2u:55: typed in front of the letter to which they belong. This imitates the traditional "layout" of typewriters where accents etc. are placed on dead keys and need to be typed before the character is typed.
GK19asvbc_2u:62: This might be formalized according to the TEI guidelines (I am not sure!!) as:
GK19asvbc_2u:65: In the TEI-Guidelines "ƒÅ" (which makes current text
GK19asvbc_2u:67: Where, as in this introductory document or in comments to variant readings within the text, the use of punctuation marks in their proper function has to alternate with their function as diacritical marks, their use as punctuation marks is
GK19asvbc_2u:68: distinguished by a following blank (or numerals or other signs of punctuation including parentheses, quotation marks etc.) or by doubling where a blank is not possible (in abbreviations,
GK19asvbc_2u:69: "e..g."). Thus, the dots in ".r.s.i" are diacritics, but the dot
GK19asvbc_2u:70: after ".r.si. " is a full stop because of the following blank.
GK19asvbc_2u:71: Similarly, since no blank can be inserted after a hyphen, the actual hyphen is written by doubling it %("p-ada--index").
GK19asvbc_2u:72: Exclamation mark is used for the da.n.da which serves as
GK19asvbc_2u:76: Annotations, remarks etc. by the editor of the transliteration
GK19asvbc_2u:78: Annotations by the editor(s) of the edition which served as
GK19asvbc_2u:79: source of the transliteration (e..g. conjectures, markers for lacunae etc.) which are part of the printed edition are enclosed
GK19asvbc_2u:83: Colophons which are part of the printed edition are enclosed by double square brackets.
GK19asvbc_2u:87: The "principle of transliteration" has been that the input format
GK19asvbc_2u:88: should reproduce the letters of the printed text as closely as possible, i..e. that one types what one sees. However, markers are added (in the transliteration) to what is printed (in
GK19asvbc_2u:89: Devan-agar-i) to indicate that fact that a printed (and
GK19asvbc_2u:90: consequently typed) letter has undergone some sandhi change.
GK19asvbc_2u:91: A sandhi change is defined with regard to the "pausa form" of a word, i..e. the form a word would take at the end of a line or out of context (vigraha). Note that this pausa form need not be identical with the stem which would be entered in a dictionary.
GK19asvbc_2u:92: Thus, (final and initial) consonants which have undergone a sandhi change in the text are marked by "*". Similarly, final vowels which have changed due to sandhi are marked by "*" (e..g.
GK19asvbc_2u:94: In case of vowel sandhi the sandhi is dissolved and marked (e..g. na*asti, ca*eva). Similarly, avagraha is reconstituted,
GK19asvbc_2u:95: the originally omitted initial "a" being marked as sandhi vowel (e..g. devo* *api).
GK19asvbc_2u:96: In some special cases the marking of sandhi has to be extended to include some disambiguating
GK19asvbc_2u:97: -- to half--vowels which substitute for a long vowel the diacritic for "long vowel" (-) is added (e..g. devy-* api);
GK19asvbc_2u:98: -- if final --a in sandhi does not stand for --a.h (with
GK19asvbc_2u:99: visarga), then the original vowel which has been substituted by
GK19asvbc_2u:100: the --a is added (e..g. lokae* eva, where "loka eva" is printed,
GK19asvbc_2u:101: which is the sandhi form for "loke eva").
GK19asvbc_2u:102: In case of "double sandhi" the sandhi is marked by double "**",
GK19asvbc_2u:103: e..g. sa**eva in case of "saiva" instead of "sa* eva").
GK19asvbc_2u:104: Blank is inserted between words wherever this is possible in transliteration (though not necessarily in Devan-agar-i), e..g.
GK19asvbc_2u:108: Another feature which exceeds what might be expected from a straightforward transliteration is the separation of nominal compounds. Separation of compounds is marked by inserting between the members of a compound (e..g. brahma+pur-a.na,
GK19asvbc_2u:109: buddha+carita). In case of sandhi, the + functions also as
GK19asvbc_2u:110: sa.mdhi--marker, i..e. no additional sandhi--marker is added (e..g. tapo+vane, mah-a+-atmana.h).
GK19asvbc_2u:111: Separation of compounds is restricted to nominal compounds (including upap-ada--compounds like ura+ga, go+p-i) and does not
GK19asvbc_2u:112: include grammatical analysis. For details, special cases etc. see the introduction to Sanskrit Indices and Text of the
GK19asvbc_2u:113: Brahmapur-a.na, Wiesbaden 1987, p. xvi--xvii, by P. Schreiner and R. S%hnen.
GK19asvbc_2u:117: The beginning of the passage for which a variant exists is marked by opening parenthesis. In deciding about the extension of the text thus marked, the changes generated for the text format had to be taken into consideration. This meant that occasionally words which are identical in the base text and in the variant are included in the parentheses, since in the text format (sa.mhita)
GK19asvbc_2u:118: the beginning of a variant could not be printed if that word is joined to the preceding word in vowel sandhi. Thus we write "...
GK19asvbc_2u:119: (mah-a+-atm-a Xmah-a+puru.sa.h) ...", even though the "mah-a+" is identical in both versions.
GK19asvbc_2u:120: The beginning of the variant is marked by a siglum, viz. by a single capital letter (capital letters are used exclusively for that purpose in the transliteration). Several sigla are separated by a comma (no blank) -- which does not occur in this file of course. There is no blank between the siglum and the variant.
GK19asvbc_2u:121: If there are several variants for the same passage of the base
GK19asvbc_2u:122: text, they are listed sequentially. The variant (or the last variant if there is more than one) is closed by the closing parenthesis. The blank before the next word is considered to
GK19asvbc_2u:123: belong to the variant and is put inside the parentheses. The continuation of the base text follows without intermediate blank.
GK19asvbc_2u:127: Interpolations are treated as "variants without base text", i..e.
GK19asvbc_2u:128: siglum follows immediately upon the opening parenthesis. The siglum is repeated before the closing parenthesis which marks the end of the interpolation. This allows for the input of variants within interpolations which are attested in more than one source.
GK19asvbc_2u:129: Long interpolations may be entered as a sequence of separate interpolations (e..g. verse by verse). Interpolated lines are
GK19asvbc_2u:130: (may be) marked by "X" at the beginning of the line (which is meant to mark "star"--passages as e..g. in the criticial edition of the MBh).
GK19asvbc_2u:133: Passages from the base text which are omitted in any of the variant texts are marked by double parentheses plus siglum enclosing the omitted passage (which may also be individual
GK19asvbc_2u:140: The full reference (chapter and verse) is given at the end of the verse to which it refers. (While transliterating the full
GK19asvbc_2u:141: reference needs to be typed only for the first verse of each
GK19asvbc_2u:142: chapter.) The reference consists of two figures separated by a
GK19asvbc_2u:143: (single) dot. The first number refers to the chapter, the second number refers to the verse--number within the chapter.
GK19asvbc_2u:144: The beginning of references is marked by double exclamation mark
GK19asvbc_2u:145: (i..e. da.n.da) and the end is marked by a single exclamation
GK19asvbc_2u:146: mark. Always after a reference a new line begins.
GK19asvbc_2u:148: The input and processing of the transliterated text has been done with TUSTEP, the Tuebingen System of Text--Processing Programs.
GK19asvbc_2u:149: The TUSTEP format includes a reference number in front of every record; this machine reference has been calculated in such a way that it agrees with the textual reference. In the ASCII--format of the input file this machine reference is lost.
GK19asvbc_2u:150: Some of the tools for textual analysis which can be produced from the input format have been published for the Brahmapur-a.na:
GK19asvbc_2u:151: Peter Schreiner, Renate Soehnen: Sanskrit Indices and Text of the
GK19asvbc_2u:153: The following list gives a survey of programs (German names in parentheses) developed for the processing of our input:
GK19asvbc_2u:154: Any of the transliterated versions (i..e. ed. Johnston or ed.
GK19asvbc_2u:156: The machine references in TUSTEP are calculated from the references in the text (REFRECHNEN).
GK19asvbc_2u:157: The text format (i..e. the conventionally transliterated text without markers; with compounds and sandhis reconstituted) can be generated (TEXTFORM). This version can be processed for output in Devan-agar-i with programs which work on the basis of transliterated input (e..g. TeX).
GK19asvbc_2u:158: The pausa format of the text is generated by changing all the characters marked by * or + according to the sandhi rules of
GK19asvbc_2u:159: Sanskrit grammar. Each word appears in the phonetic form which it
GK19asvbc_2u:160: would assume at the end of a line (e..g. -adibhir*, -adibhi.s*,
GK19asvbc_2u:161: -adibhi's*, -adhibhis* all become -adibhi.h). Members of compounds are separated. (PAUSAFORM)
GK19asvbc_2u:166: -- reverse index of wordforms (from pausa format)
GK19asvbc_2u:167: All indexes are sorted according to the Devan-agar-i alphabet and may include frequencies (absolute and relative) and formatting commands for the output.
